channel.title: Uberflip Help Center Articles - Account resources
channel.description: Latest articles from Uberflip Help Center

item.title: Make a feature request
item.description:
Got an idea that could improve Uberflip? Head to the Uberflip feedback portal and let us know! This article will show you how. 

 

Before you begin

  • Before submitting a feature request or feedback, search the feedback portal to see if it’s already been submitted. Upvoting an existing idea helps us get a better look at how popular it is. 
  • After submitting or upvoting an idea, you can check the status that idea in the Feedback portal at any time.
  • Making a feature request doesn't guarantee your idea will be built. Check out the Will my request be built? section for more details.

 

What is a feature request?  

Feature requests are a way for Uberflip users to suggest new capabilities they think all Uberflip users would love! 

Requests for a specific feature or functionality are one of the many ways that product designers look for areas of improvement in a product. We use feature requests to scope out what users are struggling to do, and build features that help them overcome that. 

Want to chat with the Uberflip Product team?

If you've got a killer idea that you think requires a deeper conversation, the Product team at Uberflip is happy to hear you out! We love chatting with our users to understand your wants and needs. Reach out to your Uberflip CSM, and they can set up a time to chat with a Product team member.   

 

Will my request be built?

Maybe! But also maybe not. This depends on a few things, such as:

  • How many users would this help?
  • How impactful would the feature be to the user experience?
  • Is it doable?
  • Is there a current workaround?
  • And much more

We must prioritize the most impactful features on our product roadmap, which already includes the new stuff the Product team is cooking up. Unfortunately, we can't build features for one account that won't be useful to others. 

In some cases we can't build what you're hoping for, and in some cases we can. But in many cases we look at the problem that’s been noted and think through different ways we can help users overcome that. Then, we'll see if and where a solution could fit into our current roadmap.

 

Submit a feature request: 

Step 1 - Access the Uberflip Feedback Portal

  1. In Uberflip, click the question mark icon in the bottom right corner

  2. Click Submit an idea >  Open in Portal

 

Step 2 - Search existing ideas

  1. Search for your idea using the search field in the top right of the feedback portal
  2. If you find that the idea has been submitted, click the thumbs-up icon to upvote it

Didn’t find your idea listed? Submit it using step 3. 

 

Step 3 - Submit your idea/feedback

  1. In the Feedback Portal, click Dashboard
  2. Click Make a Suggestion
  3. Fill out the request form, including: 
    • The feature request (or struggle you’re looking to overcome)
    • What you’re trying to achieve
    • Your current workaround (if you have one)
    • Supporting files (if you have any)
  4. Click Submit request

That’s it! Our team will review your idea/feedback. You can check on the status of your idea at anytime in the Feedback portal. 

Tip

Change your notifications preferences from the profile settings in the Feedback Portal (Profile Icon > Email Settings).

 

Feature request statuses explained

Feature requests for Uberflip can be in only 1 of 6 statuses at any given time. This section outlines exactly what each status means, so you can be fully informed about where your request is currently. 

New request 
This is a request that hasn’t been reviewed by the Uberflip Product team yet, so no decisions have been made. 

Maybe later
This is a request that we think may be a good idea, but it doesn’t fit within our current roadmap. We’ll keep it in our back pocket and revisit it in the future, but we won’t be moving forward with it at this time. 

Looking into it
This is a request that we are currently investigating. We’re looking at the scope, impact, feasibility, and more to determine if it can or should be added to our roadmap. From here, a request may move forward, but it may also be declined or moved into a “Maybe later” status depending on how our investigation goes.

In progress
A request in this status is currently being built and will likely be released. While this is a very good sign, some projects run into expected road blocks when being built, so there’s still a small chance it doesn’t get released. 

Available
This status indicates that we’ve built a feature for this and it’s been released. Often it means the request was fulfilled, but it may also indicate that the feature already existed when the request was made.

Not a fit
Some requests just aren’t a good fit for Uberflip. It may be that they can’t be built with our current resources/technology, that it won’t benefit enough users, or that it doesn’t fit into our strategies or philosophies. Either way, we won't be moving forward with this request.

item.title: Where can I find Uberflip's policies and legal documentation?
item.description:
Question

Where I can I find Uberflip's policy documentation, legal documents, Terms of Use, etc.?

 

Answer

Uberflip has a variety of policies in place that are designed to define and govern the relationship between Uberflip and you, our customers. If you would like to reference these policies, they are available on our website at uberflip.com/legal. 

The policies hosted on the legal page of our website include: 

  • Terms of use
  • Copyright policy
  • Cookie policy
  • Anti-spam policy
  • Data security policy
  • Data Processing Addendum
  • Privacy policy
  • Sub-Processor List
  • Uberflip Trial
  • Services Agreement
  • Accessibility
  • Software Support/End Of Life policy

As with all changes to our platform and services, we will do our best to keep you updated if and when changes are made to these policies.

item.title: Supported Browsers and Operating Systems
item.description:
The minimum system requirements (browser and OS) for using the Uberflip web app and other services.

 

Introduction

This article lists the supported browser and OS versions with which you can use Uberflip services, including:

  • The Uberflip web application (app.uberflip.com)
  • The Uberflip API
  • Uberflip Hubs

Uberflip services may work with browsers/operating systems not mentioned in this article (e.g. Linux), however they are only tested and guaranteed to work with the specific browsers/operating systems (and respective versions) listed below.

 

General Requirements

 To use Uberflip services, you need at least:

  • An internet connection (broadband recommended)
  • A supported browser running on a supported operating system

 

Supported Browsers

Uberflip Web App

The Uberflip web app (app.uberflip.com) is officially supported on these 4 browsers:

Browser Minimum Version Recommended Version
Chrome (desktop) 109 Latest stable version
Firefox 22 Latest stable version
Safari (desktop) 16 Latest stable version
Edge 22 Latest stable version

While Uberflip may work on other browsers, using a browser not listed here may result in unexpected issues. We may not be able to support issues on other browsers if the issue is browser specific. 

Info

The Uberflip Web App is designed for use with desktop devices/browsers, and is not optimized for mobile devices.

 

Hubs

You can view Uberflip-made sites and pages on the following browsers:

Browser Minimum Version Recommended Version
Chrome (desktop) 109 Latest stable version
Firefox 22 Latest stable version
Safari (desktop) 16 Latest stable version
Edge 22 Latest stable version

Important: OnBrand customizations and other Custom Code

The information in this section applies to standard Hub functionality only. Non-standard Hub functionality that has been implemented with Custom Code, including customizations developed by Uberflip's OnBrand team, may not be compatible with the specific browser versions indicated here.

All OnBrand-developed custom Hub functionality is tested to work with the current versions of Chrome, Firefox, and Edge at the time they were developed. Due to low usage and poor compatibility with modern web technologies, OnBrand-developed functionality is not tested for use with Internet Explorer 11, and is therefore not guaranteed to function in that browser.

 

Supported Operating Systems

Desktop

Uberflip supports the following operating systems for desktop devices:

Operating System Supported Versions
Windows 7/8/8.1/10
macOS 10.11 (El Capitan) or later

 

Mobile

Uberflip supports the following operating systems for mobile devices:

Operating System
 Supported Versions
Android 6.0.1 (Marshmallow) or later
iOS 12.0.1 or later

item.title: Reference: Uberflip IP Addresses
item.description:
A reference guide to the IP addresses used by Uberflip.

 

Usage

This reference guide lists the IP addresses used by Uberflip. These are the IP addresses that you will use to connect to Uberflip's servers, and which Uberflip's systems will use to connect to any services you host (if applicable).

This information is primarily useful for organizations which have IP restriction rules in place, e.g. an Allowed IP list that specifies the external IPs a device on your network can connect to, and/or the external IPs which may establish connections to devices on your network. Most commonly, such rules are implemented as part of a firewall or similar network security system.

Please note that we may make changes to our network infrastructure from time to time, so all IP addresses listed on this page are subject to change.

Caution

The IP addresses listed on this page should only be used for the purpose of configuring IP restriction rules. In all other instances where an Uberflip IP address might be applicable (e.g. when configuring DNS records or reverse proxy configurations for custom domains), you should always use the domain read.uberflip.com instead of an IP address.

 

Uberflip Inbound IPs

To access any Uberflip domain or service (including the Uberflip application), you must be able to connect to all of the following IP addresses:

52.60.165.183
52.60.160.16
3.98.63.202

If your organization restricts the IP addresses that devices on your network can connect to, you should ensure the IP addresses listed above are added to your Allowed IP list.

 

Uberflip Outbound IPs

The following IP addresses are used by Uberflip to establish connections to external (customer) systems:

35.182.205.201
35.182.103.172
3.96.250.25

If your organization hosts or uses a service that Uberflip needs to connect to, and you restrict the IP addresses which can connect to these services, you should ensure that the IP addresses listed above are added to your Allowed IP list. Examples of applicable services include:

  • Private FTP/SFTP servers that Uberflip connects to in order to download PDFs to convert to Flipbooks
  • Private RSS feeds that are connected to Streams in your Uberflip Hub
  • Marketing Automation Platforms (e.g. Marketo, Eloqua, HubSpot, etc.) or Custom Form CTAs that Uberflip connects to for progressive profiling of visitors and for capturing Form CTA submissions and activity data

item.title: Where is my Uberflip data stored?
item.description:
Question

Where does Uberflip store data related to my Hub? Where are Uberflip's servers located?

 

Answer

Uberflip hosts customer Hubs (and all associated data, such as as Uberflip Analytics data) on Amazon Web Services (AWS) in the Canada (Central) AWS Region. We also keep off-site backups in the US East (N. Virginia) Region.

item.title: Register for an Uberflip Help Account
item.description:
Learn how to sign up for an Uberflip Help account to manage your support requests, comment on articles, and more.

 

What is an Uberflip Help account?

Uberflip Help is our help center. You're in it right now! This is where you can find our knowledge resources, like how-to and troubleshooting articles, as well as submit support requests if you need help.

An Uberflip Help account lets you to sign in to our help center to access additional functionality. With an Uberflip Helps account, you can:

  • View and manage your own support requests, both current and past (if enabled, you can also manage requests submitted by others in your organization — contact your Uberflip representative to learn more)
  • Comment on articles to leave feedback or ask questions
  • Follow articles so that you're automatically notified if they're updated
  • Get access to pre-release articles if you're participating in a beta or early access program

I already have an Uberflip account — can I just use that?

You use your Uberflip account to sign into the Uberflip app at app.uberflip.com. This is a different type of account than an Uberflip Help account, which is used to sign in to our help center at help.uberflip.com.

As a result, you can't sign in to Uberflip Help with your Uberflip account: to sign in here, you'll need to register separately for an Uberflip Help account.

 

Do I need an Uberflip Help account?

Registering for an Uberflip Help account is completely optional. Signing up for an account simply gives you access to some extra functionality in our help center.

Even if you do not have an Uberflip Help account, you'll still be able to submit support requests and browse our knowledge base without any restrictions.

 

How do I get an Uberflip Help account?

To get started, just click on Sign in in the top right of any page in the help center:

What you do next depends on whether you've contacted us before:

I have previously emailed Uberflip Support or opened a support request

If you've contacted us in the past, you an Uberflip Help account has been created for you automatically. To use it, you just have to finish setting it up:

  1. Click on Get a password:
  2. Enter the email you used to contact us, then click on Submit:
  3. You should receive an email within a few minutes. Just click on the link in the email to choose a password for your account and complete the registration.
I have never contacted Uberflip Support

If you haven't gotten in touch with us yet, you'll need to sign up for a new account:

  1. Click on Sign up:
  2. Type in your name and email (make sure you use your work email!) and check the box in the CAPTCHA field, then click on the Sign up button:
  3. You should receive an email within a few minutes. Just click on the link in the email to choose a password for your account and complete the registration.

Once you've registered for your account, you'll be able to sign in to Uberflip Help at any time by simply clicking on Sign in in the top right again.

 

Having Trouble?

If you're having trouble signing up for an Uberflip Help account, this may be due to a setting in your browser. See this article for help:

Can't sign up for an Uberflip Help account

item.title: Severity levels and response times for support requests
item.description:
Wondering what Severity means when you submit a support request? Learn how the different severity levels are defined, and which one you should choose for your ticket.

 

What is "Severity"?

Not all support requests are the same: sometimes you might need to let us know that your entire Hub is broken, while other times you just want to ask a question.

That's why we ask you to indicate the severity of the issue you're experiencing whenever you submit a support ticket to the Uberflip Support team:

The Severity field is how you tell us how big of an impact the issue is having on your system. Choosing the right severity level for your request is important, because it helps the Support team to prioritize your request and ensure it's resolved in a timely manner.

 

How do I choose a severity level?

There are five severity levels, representing a scale that ranges from critical impact (Severity 1) to no impact (Severity 5). Remember: lower severity level number = higher impact.

Each severity level has a particular definition, which you can see in the table below. These definitions are intended as guidelines: use them to find the severity level that is the best fit for the issue you're experiencing, even if it doesn't match the definition exactly.

Severity Level Impact Definition Committed Initial Response Time
Severity 1 Critical

A production system is down or a mission critical failure in a production system is imminent.

This is a showstopper: the system is not usable until the issue is fixed, and no workaround is available.

1 Hour
Severity 2 High

The issue is causing a loss of key functionality which affects significant aspects of the business or operations.

Something major isn't working, but the system is still usable to an extent.

3 Hours
Severity 3 Moderate

The issue affects an isolated component, but this is not affecting the ability of the system to perform in accordance with the documentation.

In general, the system is working normally except for a limited portion.

6 Hours
Severity 4 Low

A minor issue: the system is still fully usable with limitations or workarounds

24 Hours
Severity 5 None This request is about something with no system impact. This includes things like feature requests, account requests, general inquiries, etc. 48 Hours

Important

Note that each severity level is associated with an initial response time commitment (or "SLA"). This means that when you choose a particular severity level, you can expect an initial response within the indicated time.

Keep in mind that "initial response" means that Support will look at your ticket and send you a reply within the specified time — it does not necessarily mean that your issue will be resolved during that time.

 

What if I choose the wrong severity level?

Don't worry too much about getting the severity level for your support request "just right". Its purpose is to help us understand and prioritize your issue as quickly as possible, so just do your best to choose the severity level that best represents the situation, using the definitions above as a guide.

If necessary, we may adjust the severity level of your ticket so that it more accurately reflects the impact of the issue. If that happens, we will of course let you know, and explain why the change was made.

And remember, choosing a lower-impact severity level doesn't mean you'll have to wait a long time for a reply! Even if you submit a Severity 5 ticket, you'll still get an initial response within 48 hours at most.

item.title: Get Your Uberflip API Key and Secret, Account ID, and Hub IDs
item.description:
To use the Uberflip API and create custom app integrations, you'll need your API Key and API Secret (and, for some things, your Hub ID). Here's how to get them.

 

Before you begin

  • To generate or delete an API Key and API Secret, you must be an Account Administrator on your Uberflip account.
  • Your API Key and API Secret are account credentials: they give access to your Uberflip account. Make sure to treat them the way you would any other username and password, i.e. keep them secret and share them only with trusted parties.
  • Your API Key and API Secret are required to use the Uberflip API. For more information, see our API documentation.
  • Uberflip API access is not available with some account types. If you do not see the Rest API Credentials section (as described in this article) in your own account, your account type may not have API access. For help, please contact your Customer Success Manager, or Uberflip Support.

 

Generate a REST API Key & Secret

  1. Log in to your Uberflip account.
  2. In the top right corner, hover the mouse over your name to expand the menu, then click on Account Settings.

  3. In the sidebar menu on the left, click on Integration to expand that section, then click on REST API Credentials.

  4. On the right, click on Generate API Key & Secret.

  5. Your API Key and API Secret will appear, along with a time signature that shows when they were generated.



    Note

    The API Key and Secret are specific to the user viewing them, so each user who has access to the Rest API Credentials page will see their own credentials.

 

Delete an API Key & Secret

It's a good security practice to rotate your API credentials periodically, which essentially means deleting the existing API Key and Secret and generating new ones. This will help to keep your account secure if your API credentials should become compromised. Of course, you should also do this immediately whenever you suspect that your API credentials have become compromised.

  1. Log in to your account and navigate to Account Settings > Integration > REST API Credentials.
  2. You should see your existing API Key and Secret listed on the right. Below them, click on the Delete API Key & Signature.

  3. In the confirmation prompt that appears, click on OK, and your API credentials will disappear.
  4. The deleted credentials will immediately be deactivated, so you will have to update any integrations you have created using them with new credentials. To do that, generate new API credentials by clicking on Generate API Key & Secret again.

 

Get an Account ID

In some cases, you may be asked to provide an Account ID. This is a string of numbers that uniquely identifies your Uberflip account, and is required to set up some integrations and Marketplace apps. Each Uberflip account only has one Account ID, which covers all the Hubs under that account.

  1. Log in to your account and navigate to Account Settings.
  2. In the sidebar menu on the left, click on Account > My Profile (if necessary; you should be on this page by default when opening Account Settings).
  3. On the My Profile page shown on the right, look for the line labeled Account ID:
  4. The string of numbers in the grey oval is your Account ID.
    • Don't confuse this with your User ID, which is shown directly above the Account ID.

 

Get a Hub ID

Sometimes, in addition to or instead of the Account ID, you may need to enter the Hub ID of the Hub you want to work with. This is a string of numbers that uniquely identifies a particular Hub, so each Hub in your account will have a its own Hub ID.

  1. Log in to your Uberflip account and click on Hubs in the top menu bar to expand the Hubs menu.
  2. Click on the Hub for which you want to get the Hub ID.
  3. By default, this should take you to the Manage Content menu. Now, look at the URL bar in your browser. You will see something like: 
    https://app.uberflip.com/hubs/content/12345
  4. The string of numbers at the end ("12345" in the example above) is the current Hub's Hub ID.
